channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Vehicle plunges off Malibu road, killing one
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: A vehicle plunged about 100 feet over the side of a road in Malibu on Tuesday, killing one person and injuring another.
item.content:encoded: A vehicle plunged about 100 feet over the side of a road in Malibu on Tuesday, killing one person and injuring another.

item.title: Son of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar charged with stabbing neighbor
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Adam Abdul-Jabbar, the son of famed Lakers star Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, faces criminal charges of repeatedly stabbing his neighbor after getting into an argument over trash cans, prosecutors say.
item.content:encoded: Adam Abdul-Jabbar, the son of famed Lakers star Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, faces criminal charges of repeatedly stabbing his neighbor after getting into an argument over trash cans, prosecutors say.

media:content.media:description: CELEBRITY FAMILY FEUD - "Harvey Family Men vs Harvey Family Women and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar vs Ralph Sampson"- The celebrity teams competing to win cash for their charities features Steve Harvey's wife, Marjorie Harvey, leading a team with their sons and sons-in-law, and the other team will be led by Mrs. Harvey's mother and the Harvey daughters. In a separate game, family members from the NBA's all-time leading scorer and six-time NBA champion Kareem Abdul-Jabbar will take on retired NBA Legend Ralph Sampson and his family. This episode of "Celebrity Family Feud" airs SUNDAY, JUNE 25 (8:00-9:00 p.m. EDT), on The Walt Disney Television via Getty Images Television Network.. (Eric McCandless/Walt Disney Television via Getty Images) STEVE HARVEY, KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, ADAM ABDUL-JABBAR, ROSE-ANN SWANN
media:content.media:credit: Eric McCandless/Walt Disney Television via Getty

item.title: Judge denies L.A. County's request to stop Grace Community Church from gathering
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: The evangelical church in Sun Valley has held its weekly Sunday services since July 26, in defiance of state and county health orders. This led L.A. County officials to file a lawsuit against the church.
item.content:encoded: The evangelical church in Sun Valley has held its weekly Sunday services since July 26, in defiance of state and county health orders. This led L.A. County officials to file a lawsuit against the church.

media:content.media:description: Grace Community Church in Sun Valley appears in an image from Google Maps.

item.title: L.A. County COVID-19 cases continue to drop, setting up potential for some school reopenings
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The 14-day average number of coronavirus cases in Los Angeles County has dropped below 200 per 100,000 residents, according to the California Department of Public Health.
item.content:encoded: The 14-day average number of coronavirus cases in Los Angeles County has dropped below 200 per 100,000 residents, according to the California Department of Public Health.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST 19, 2020: Gladys Alvarez, a 5th grade teacher at Manchester Ave. Elementary School in South Los Angeles, talks to her students during a meet and greet on Wednesday afternoon. Alvarez was sitting inside her empty classroom while conducting the virtual zoom class. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Feeling anxious and depressed? In California, you're right at home
item.dc:creator: Phillip Reese
item.description: It's official, California: COVID-19 has left us sick with worry and increasingly despondent. And young adults — ages 18 to 29 — are feeling it worst.
item.content:encoded: It's official, California: COVID-19 has left us sick with worry and increasingly despondent. And young adults — ages 18 to 29 — are feeling it worst.

media:content.media:description: Children suffered worse health when their mothers were depressed, a new study has found.

item.title: California moves to stop excessive punishment of Black and disabled students at three districts
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: Settlements with districts in Barstow and Oroville follow investigations by the California Department of Justice into discipline of Black and disabled students.
item.content:encoded: Settlements with districts in Barstow and Oroville follow investigations by the California Department of Justice into discipline of Black and disabled students.

media:content.media:description: High school students celebrate the Los Angeles Unified School District's decision to ban student suspensions for "willful defiance."
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: LAPD will keep testing BolaWrap, a device meant to immobilize suspects from a distance
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: L.A. police will continue testing the BolaWrap, a tether restraint designed to help immobilize suspects from a distance, after a pilot program produced too little data.
item.content:encoded: L.A. police will continue testing the BolaWrap, a tether restraint designed to help immobilize suspects from a distance, after a pilot program produced too little data.

media:content.media:description: The BolaWrap devices are about size of a larger cell phone.

item.title: Gov. Gavin Newsom endorses George Gascón in Los Angeles County D.A.'s race
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom endorsed George Gascón on Tuesday in his bid to unseat Jackie Lacey as Los Angeles County's district attorney.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom endorsed George Gascón on Tuesday in his bid to unseat Jackie Lacey as Los Angeles County's district attorney.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, May 14, 2020. Reflecting the financial hit California is already seeing from the coronavirus, Newsom proposed cutting $6.1 billion from a variety of programs in a state budget he says prioritizes public education, public health and public safety. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Lobbyist agrees to plea deal in L.A. City Hall corruption case
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Joel Rubin
item.description: Longtime lobbyist and former Los Angeles City Hall official Morrie Goldman has agreed to plead guilty in pay-to-play corruption case.
item.content:encoded: Longtime lobbyist and former Los Angeles City Hall official Morrie Goldman has agreed to plead guilty in pay-to-play corruption case.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles City Ethics Commission has fined lobbyist John Ek $11,000 for inviting city officials to a birthday party at a downtown restaurant.

item.title: 'Significant progress' as weather helps in battle against historic Northern California wildfires
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The monster blazes burning across California saw limited growth overnight as firefighters worked to increase containment.
item.content:encoded: The monster blazes burning across California saw limited growth overnight as firefighters worked to increase containment.

media:content.media:description: VACAVILLE, CA - AUGUST 24: The phrase "Vaca Strong" is seen on a burnt out hillside along Pleasants Creek Road where the LNU Lightning complex fire tore through late last week, photographed on Monday, Aug. 24, 2020 in Vacaville, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Island Express sues air traffic controllers in Kobe Bryant crash
item.dc:creator: Nathan Fenno
item.description: Island Express, the company that operated the helicopter involved in the fatal Kobe Bryant crash, blames air traffic controllers for causing accident.
item.content:encoded: Island Express, the company that operated the helicopter involved in the fatal Kobe Bryant crash, blames air traffic controllers for causing accident.

media:content.media:description: EXCLUSIVE: June 17, 2019 - San Diego, California, United States: Sikorsky S76, tail number N72EX, piloted by Ara Zobayan. On January 26, 2020, Kobe Bryant and his daughter Gianna were among nine people on board when this Sikorsky crashed in a Calabasas mountain area killing all passengers and the pilot. (Polaris) ///

item.title: Squaw Valley ski resort to drop 'squaw' from name
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows, near Lake Tahoe, plans to drop the derogatory term 'squaw' from its name.
item.content:encoded: Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows, near Lake Tahoe, plans to drop the derogatory term 'squaw' from its name.

media:content.media:description: The Olympic rings stand atop a sign at the entrance to the Squaw Valley Ski Resort in Olympic Valley, Calif., July 8, 2020. California's Squaw Valley Ski Resort is considering changing its name to remove "squaw," a derogatory term for Native American women. Squaw Valley President & CEO Ron Cohen says resort officials are meeting with shareholders and the local Washoe tribal leadership to get their input. He says he can't give a timeline on when the decision will be made. The renaming of Squaw Valley Ski Resort is one of many efforts across the nation to address colonialism and indigenous oppression. (AP Photo/Haven Daley)

item.title: FBI assisting in search for L.A. firefighter missing in Mexico
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Francisco Aguilar, a 20-year veteran of the Los Angeles Fire Department, disappeared from his condo in Rosarito, according to family members.
item.content:encoded: Francisco Aguilar, a 20-year veteran of the Los Angeles Fire Department, disappeared from his condo in Rosarito, according to family members.

media:content.media:description: Family members gathered for a vigil to pray for the safe return of a Los Angeles firefighter and Army veteran who disappeared last week in Mexico. Francisco Aguilar, a 20-year veteran of the Los Angeles Fire Department, disappeared from his condo in Rosarit

item.title: The coronavirus gave them jobs — and a new lease on life
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Some just got out of prison; others came off the streets. They are practically unemployable. But thanks to COVID-19, an L.A. nonprofit is able to put them to work at hotels taken over to house the homeless during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Some just got out of prison; others came off the streets. They are practically unemployable. But thanks to COVID-19, an L.A. nonprofit is able to put them to work at hotels taken over to house the homeless during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 21, 2020 - - Guest services associate Mia Rogers, 23, left, gives Project Roomkey guest Stanley Monk, 58, his lunch under the watchful eye of LVN Richard F. at a Project Roomkey hotel in Los Angeles on July 22, 2020. Rogers, a client of Chrysalis, lost her job due to the coronavirus pandemic. She was hired to work at a Project Roomkey hotel. About 100 clients of Chrysalis, a downtown agency that gets work for homeless people who lost their jobs because of the virus shutdowns. They've been rehired by Project Roomkey to work in hotels. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hope takes flight: L.A.'s Natural History Museum will reopen its Butterfly Pavilion & gardens
item.dc:creator: Deborah Vankin
item.description: The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County will open its Butterfly Pavilion to members starting Aug. 28 and to the public on Sept. 11.
item.content:encoded: The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County will open its Butterfly Pavilion to members starting Aug. 28 and to the public on Sept. 11.

item.title: Only 3% of UC Irvine students are Black. The 'Black Thriving Initiative' aims to change that
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The death of George Floyd while in police custody has inspired UC Irvine to launch a new effort to build a thriving campus climate for Black students, faculty and staff.
item.content:encoded: The death of George Floyd while in police custody has inspired UC Irvine to launch a new effort to build a thriving campus climate for Black students, faculty and staff.

media:content.media:description: UC Irvine student Jared Childress leads a group of students and faculty in the rally, which was part of a week-long series of events celebrating the life and legacy of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Wednesday's march began at the Student Center terrace and proceeded around Ring Mall.

item.title: California counties stuck in limbo as they wait for Newsom's reopening rules
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Eight California counties have slowed the spread of the coronavirus but are unable to reopen businesses until Gov. Gavin Newsom releases new guidelines.
item.content:encoded: Eight California counties have slowed the spread of the coronavirus but are unable to reopen businesses until Gov. Gavin Newsom releases new guidelines.

item.title: In Bonny Doon, a 'ragtag outfit' stays behind to save homes from wildfires
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Susanne Rust
item.description: As fires burn throughout the Santa Cruz Mountains, some residents of Bonny Doon are staying put and fighting the fires that outside agencies can't or won't take on.
item.content:encoded: As fires burn throughout the Santa Cruz Mountains, some residents of Bonny Doon are staying put and fighting the fires that outside agencies can't or won't take on.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters Cody Nordstrom, Kyle Harp and Robert Gonzalez, from left, of the North Central Fire station out of Kerman, Calif., look up at a water-dropping helicopter while fighting the CZU Lightning Complex Fire on Sunday, Aug. 23, 2020, in Bonny Doon, Calif. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)

item.title: Commentary: Why Grand Avenue and Frank Gehry are L.A.'s path out of the pandemic
item.dc:creator: Mark Swed
item.description: Build Frank Gehry's Colburn School concert hall. Renovate Disney Hall. Update the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. The investments will pay off, big time.
item.content:encoded: Build Frank Gehry's Colburn School concert hall. Renovate Disney Hall. Update the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion. The investments will pay off, big time.

media:content.media:description: A rendering shows the planned Grand Avenue project, a $1-billion complex with apartments, hotel rooms, restaurants and shops across from Walt Disney Concert Hall.

item.title: Handcuffed Black suspect said, 'I can't breathe,' as L.A. firefighter allegedly struck him
item.dc:creator: Paul Pringle, Kevin Rector, Dakota Smith
item.description: A white L.A. firefighter allegedly struck a Black man who was handcuffed on a gurney. The firefighter remains on duty pending a rights hearing.
item.content:encoded: A white L.A. firefighter allegedly struck a Black man who was handcuffed on a gurney. The firefighter remains on duty pending a rights hearing.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles Fire Department rapidly reversed a decision to put its social media accounts on hiatus and halt releasing records that show how long it takes rescuers to respond to calls for help.

item.title: Hundreds of protesters take to streets of downtown L.A. to decry police shootings
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Luke Money
item.description: Police declared the protest an unlawful assembly about 11:20 p.m., and officers began moving the group away from LAPD headquarters after midnight.
item.content:encoded: Police declared the protest an unlawful assembly about 11:20 p.m., and officers began moving the group away from LAPD headquarters after midnight.

media:content.media:description: LAPD officers in riot gear stood watch in front of Los Angeles Police Department headquarters late Monday night as a protesters rallied against two police shootings in the past nine days. The group was protesting the Aug. 15 deadly police shooting of Anthony McClain in Pasadena and Sunday's shooting of Jacob Blake in Kenosha, Wisconsin,

item.title: Garcetti says new appointee to Police Commission 'meets the moment'
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti has appointed Lou Calanche, a youth advocate and nonprofit executive from Ramona Gardens, to the city's five-member Police Commission, pending approval by the City Council.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti has appointed Lou Calanche, a youth advocate and nonprofit executive from Ramona Gardens, to the city's five-member Police Commission, pending approval by the City Council.

item.content:encoded: George Gascón's campaign accused L.A. Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey of misusing public resources during her campaign.

media:content.media:description: Left, Los Angeles County District Attorney Jackie Lacey during a press conference at the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles, Calif., on Nov. 15, 2019. Right, former San Francisco District Attorney George Gascon took part in the debate at the California African-American Museum on Wednesday, Dec. 11, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: O.C. man masquerading for years as federal agent pulled over motorists, obtained guns, feds allege
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: For years, investigators say, Donovan Nguyen has masqueraded as a federal agent, carrying firearms, pulling over motorists and purchasing guns with fake law enforcement credentials.
item.content:encoded: For years, investigators say, Donovan Nguyen has masqueraded as a federal agent, carrying firearms, pulling over motorists and purchasing guns with fake law enforcement credentials.

media:content.media:description: Donovan Nguyen was arrested Monday and charged with impersonating a federal agent.

item.title: Ban on flavored tobacco sales is approved by California Assembly
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The California Assembly on Monday approved a ban on the retail sale of flavored tobacco products in the state, with supporters saying it is needed to reduce smoking and vaping by minors and others attracted by fruit and menthol flavors.
item.content:encoded: The California Assembly on Monday approved a ban on the retail sale of flavored tobacco products in the state, with supporters saying it is needed to reduce smoking and vaping by minors and others attracted by fruit and menthol flavors.

media:content.media:description: Menthol cigarettes appear to be more addictive and pose a greater health threat than unflavored tobacco, an FDA report says.

item.title: Abandoned by authorities, these fire-threatened towns set up their own FEMA-like response
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: They couldn't get help from the state. Or the feds. So volunteer firefighters in two Santa Cruz mountain towns tapped an elite network of emergency responders.
item.content:encoded: They couldn't get help from the state. Or the feds. So volunteer firefighters in two Santa Cruz mountain towns tapped an elite network of emergency responders.

item.title: School district suspends online classes after malware attack in Rialto
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: Online learning for more than 25,000 students has stopped indefinitely while officials research the computer attack and collect all equipment issued to teachers and students.
item.content:encoded: Online learning for more than 25,000 students has stopped indefinitely while officials research the computer attack and collect all equipment issued to teachers and students.

item.title: Op-Ed: Pandemics spread like wildfire, and fire is a contagion too
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Pyne
item.description: Fire is like COVID-19. The only response that works is systemic preparedness.
item.content:encoded: Fire is like COVID-19. The only response that works is systemic preparedness.

media:content.media:description: Flames from the LNU Lightning Complex fires consume a home in unincorporated Napa County, Calif., on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Proposed California ban on flavored tobacco sales sparks discussion of systemic racism
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Supporters of Senate Bill 793 say that a new ad from big tobacco falsely and cynically portrays itself as an ally of people of color.
item.content:encoded: Supporters of Senate Bill 793 say that a new ad from big tobacco falsely and cynically portrays itself as an ally of people of color.

media:content.media:description: Menthol cigarettes pose a greater health risk to the public than unflavored tobacco, an FDA report says. The flavored cigarettes are more enticing, the agency suggests.

item.title: USC reports 'alarming increase' in COVID-19 cases
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: Just a week into fall semester, USC reported that 43 students had tested positive for COVID-19 and more than100 placed in quarantine because of exposure.
item.content:encoded: Just a week into fall semester, USC reported that 43 students had tested positive for COVID-19 and more than100 placed in quarantine because of exposure.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17, 2020 - - USC student Jesus Carreon, 21, locks up his bike under a sign that states three steps to keep the coronavirus at bay on the first day of academic instruction for the Fall 2020 semester on the USC campus in Los Angeles on August 17, 2020. Carreon wanted to do his homework on a nearby patio to have some semblance of a college experience. Students were taking online courses off campus due to the coronavirus pandemic and the university was nearly empty. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: More counties removed from California's COVID-19 watchlist

item.description: Three more counties came off California's COVID-19 watchlist over the weekend after showing a decline in case counts and transmission rates for three consecutive days.
item.content:encoded: Three more counties came off California's COVID-19 watchlist over the weekend after showing a decline in case counts and transmission rates for three consecutive days.

item.title: Shyong: Kamala Harris' identity shows us the limits of our labels
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: It was just the Tamil word for auntie, two syllables in a speech by Kamala Harris last Thursday that covered her childhood, heritage and political awakening and culminated in her acceptance of the Democratic Party nomination for vice president.
item.content:encoded: It was just the Tamil word for auntie, two syllables in a speech by Kamala Harris last Thursday that covered her childhood, heritage and political awakening and culminated in her acceptance of the Democratic Party nomination for vice president.

media:content.media:description: Kamala Harris, back row from left, with grandparents Rajam Gopalan and P.V. Gopalan and sister Maya Harris. In front are Maya's daughter, Meena, left, and the Harrises' cousin Sharada Balachandran Orihuela

item.title: In a rural California town, schools try something extraordinary and risky: Classrooms with children
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: In a vast, rural Northern California county with few cases of COVID-19, a public school district reopened to in-classroom instruction, even as most in the state are doing virtual distance learning.
item.content:encoded: In a vast, rural Northern California county with few cases of COVID-19, a public school district reopened to in-classroom instruction, even as most in the state are doing virtual distance learning.

media:content.media:description: WEAVERVILLE, CA - AUGUST 17: Darsi Green speaks to students in her second grade glass at Weaverville Elementary School on the first day on returning to in-person instruction on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020 in Weaverville, CA. The Trinity Alps Unified School District reopened amid the coronavirus pandemic, resuming in-person classroom instruction. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Landlords need to stop whining about the unfairness of California's eviction ban
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: With millions at risk of eviction, renters must come first as California's governor and lawmakers try to reach a legislative compromise with landlords.
item.content:encoded: With millions at risk of eviction, renters must come first as California's governor and lawmakers try to reach a legislative compromise with landlords.

item.title: Northern California fires rage on: 'We are essentially living in a mega fire era'
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money, Alex Wigglesworth, Joe Mozingo
item.description: Firefighters saw a welcome respite in dangerous fire weather with the cancellation of a red-flag warning for the Bay Area.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters saw a welcome respite in dangerous fire weather with the cancellation of a red-flag warning for the Bay Area.

media:content.media:description: BEN LOMOND, CA - AUGUST 21: Firefighters work to contain a blaze during the CZU August Lightning Complex Fires on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020 in Ben Lomond, CA. The University of California at Santa Cruz campus and nearby towns have been under evacuation orders due to fires in the region. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Death of an Indigenous essential worker sparks debate over gender identity
item.dc:creator: Tomás Mier
item.description: Angela Martinez said she was neither man, nor woman, nor transgender. She was muxe, a third gender recognized in the Zapotec culture in Mexico.
item.content:encoded: Angela Martinez said she was neither man, nor woman, nor transgender. She was muxe, a third gender recognized in the Zapotec culture in Mexico.

media:content.media:description: RESEDA, CA - AUGUST 18: Portrait of Pink Moon Midnight Blue holding a photo of her friend Angela Martinez, left, on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Reseda, CA. Pink Moon Midnight Blue, was a close friend of Angela Martinez, who died recently of COVID. Martinez identified herself as "muxe," third gender recognized by the Zapotec indigenous community in Mexico. Midnight Blue is transgender and said Martinez pointedly said she was neither man, nor woman, nor trans, but muxe. Midnight Blue is wearing a dress given to her by Martinez. She said Martinez was like a mother to her. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: California is too dependent on the rich. Now isn't the time for another millionaires' tax
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: The top 1% of California taxpayers kick in nearly half the state income tax. California is already leaning very heavily on its richest citizens — too heavily for good tax policy.
item.content:encoded: The top 1% of California taxpayers kick in nearly half the state income tax. California is already leaning very heavily on its richest citizens — too heavily for good tax policy.

media:content.media:description: Large boxes full of already opened and emptied envelopes sit at the Franchise Tax Board before being recycled in Sacramento. The last six months generated $2 billion more income tax revenue than expected, according to a new report from the nonpartisan Legislative Analyst's Office.

item.title: Orange County removed from California's coronavirus watch list
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: If the rates of new cases and tests performed, percentages of positive tests and hospitalizations, as well as available intensive care beds and ventilators remain at acceptable levels for the next two weeks, K-12 students could resume in-person classes after Labor Day weekend.
item.content:encoded: If the rates of new cases and tests performed, percentages of positive tests and hospitalizations, as well as available intensive care beds and ventilators remain at acceptable levels for the next two weeks, K-12 students could resume in-person classes after Labor Day weekend.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST 19, 2020: Gladys Alvarez, a 5th grade teacher at Manchester Ave. Elementary School in South Los Angeles, waves goodbye to her students at conclusion of a meet and greet on Wednesday afternoon. Alvarez was sitting inside her empty classroom while conducting the virtual zoom class. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UCLA area again flooded by water line break, Sunset Boulevard shut down in Westwood
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: An underground 30-inch water line broke in Westwood overnight, causing gushing water to knock down two trees and shut down Sunset Boulevard.
item.content:encoded: An underground 30-inch water line broke in Westwood overnight, causing gushing water to knock down two trees and shut down Sunset Boulevard.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 23, 2020 - - Workers with DWP and Public Work Street Services look over the site where an underground water line break occurred causing flooding and bringing down two trees which blocked Sunset Blvd. near UCLA in Los Angeles on August 23, 2020. No lives were put in danger by the floodwaters in the 10600 block of West Sunset Blvd, which were reported at 1:35 a.m. No one needed to be rescued, according to the L.A. Fire Department, which arrived on scene before the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. No evacuations were necessary, LAFD spokesperson Brian Humphrey said. The flood hasn't impacted student housing. According to Humphrey, a residential property to the north of Sunset did take on water. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

The CZU August Lightning complex fires tore through Big Basin Redwoods State Park, decimating the 118-year-old state park - California's oldest. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Another coronavirus inequity: Those who can afford to stay in place and those who must move

item.content:encoded: A new UC Davis study links social distancing to income, showing America's wealthy have become its least mobile while poorer people face more exposure.

item.title: 'Fires of hell': How dry lightning has sparked some of California's biggest infernos
item.dc:creator: Bettina Boxall
item.description: Many of California's largest wildfires have been started by dry lightning strikes
item.content:encoded: Many of California's largest wildfires have been started by dry lightning strikes

media:content.media:description: A rare lightning storm crackles over Mitchell's Cove in Santa Cruz, California around 3 a.m. Sunday morning August 16, 2020. The severe storm system rolled through the San Francisco and Monterey Bay areas early Sunday, packing a combination of dry lightning and high winds that triggered wildfires throughout the region. The National Weather Service on Sunday extended a red flag fire warning for the entire Bay Area until 11 a.m. Monday morning. (Shmuel Thaler/The Santa Cruz Sentinel via AP)

item.title: Megan Thee Stallion had a gunshot wound needing surgery after she says Tory Lanez shot her

In an Instagram Live video Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020, hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion said for the first time that fellow rapper Tory Lanez was the person who pulled the trigger when she was shot in the feet after a party in the Hollywood Hills more than a month earlier. (Photo by Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP, File)

item.title: UCLA sharply scales back reopening plans under strict county rules
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: UCLA will further scale back fall reopening plans, sharply limiting on-campus housing and in-person classes, to comply with strict L.A. County public health rules on what local colleges and universities must do to protect against the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: UCLA will further scale back fall reopening plans, sharply limiting on-campus housing and in-person classes, to comply with strict L.A. County public health rules on what local colleges and universities must do to protect against the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 05, 2020 - - A lone jogger runs past Royce Hall on a nearly empty UCLA campus in Los Angeles on August 13, 2020. The empty campus is a preview of what the Fall semester will look like during the coronavirus pandemic. Most classes, much like the summer classes, will be held online at the university. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's job growth slowed dramatically in July: August will likely be worse
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: California's job growth decelerates last month, lagging the overall U.S., amid rising COVID-19 infections and shuttered businesses.
item.content:encoded: California's job growth decelerates last month, lagging the overall U.S., amid rising COVID-19 infections and shuttered businesses.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 6, 2020. A waman walks past a shuttered restaurant in Los Angeles on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020. Weeks after the social unrest following Floyd's death, some of the looted and vadalized stores downtown remain boarded up. Many downtown stores and eateries also remain shuttered or restricted because of coronavirus. Leases and rents are spiraling downward, and large numbers of homeless people live on the streets. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Building owners connected to massive downtown L.A. explosion face 300 criminal charges
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, James Queally
item.description: The L.A. city attorney has filed more than 300 charges against the owners of four downtown buildings after a May 16 explosion burned 11 firefighters.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. city attorney has filed more than 300 charges against the owners of four downtown buildings after a May 16 explosion burned 11 firefighters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 16: Firefighters first received a call about 6:30 p.m. about a structure fire in the 300 block of Boyd Street south of Little Tokyo, said Erik Scott, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Fire Department, in downtown on Saturday, May 16, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The fire left 11 firefighters injured, authorities said. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Admissions scandal: Lori Loughlin sentenced to 2 months in prison; Giannulli gets 5 months
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: For fixing their daughters' admission to USC, Lori Loughlin and J. Mossimo Giannulli were sentenced to two months and five months, respectively, in prison.
item.content:encoded: For fixing their daughters' admission to USC, Lori Loughlin and J. Mossimo Giannulli were sentenced to two months and five months, respectively, in prison.

media:content.media:description: BOSTON, MA - AUGUST 27: Lori Loughlin and her husband Mossimo Giannulli, right, leave the John Joseph Moakley United States Courthouse in Boston on Aug. 27, 2019. A judge says actress Lori Loughlin and her fashion designer husband, Mossimo Giannulli, can continue using a law firm that recently represented the University of Southern California. The couple appeared in Boston federal court on Tuesday to settle a dispute over their choice of lawyers in a sweeping college admissions bribery case. Prosecutors had said their lawyers pose a potential conflict of interest. Loughlin and Giannulli say the firms work for USC was unrelated to the admissions case and was handled by different lawyers. (Photo by John Tlumacki/The Boston Globe via Getty Images)

item.title: Golden State Killer given life in prison for rapes, murders that terrorized a generation
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John, Luke Money
item.description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., a former cop who murdered 13 people and raped more than 50 women and girls, was sentenced to life in prison.
item.content:encoded: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., a former cop who murdered 13 people and raped more than 50 women and girls, was sentenced to life in prison.

media:content.media:description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. at his sentencing held at CSU Sacramento on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020, in Sacramento, Calif. DeAngelo Jr., 74, was sentenced to 11 life sentences in prison without the possibility of parole, one life sentence with the possibility of parole and an additional eight year sentence under a plea agreement that allowed him to avoid the death sentence. In June, DeAngelo Jr. admitted being the infamous Golden State Killer. The former police officer in California eluded capture for four decades. He admitted killing 13 people and raping nearly 50 people in the 1970s and 1980s. The sentencing was held at the University Union, a large enough space so that people could maintain physical distance, amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: The surprising story of the salesman who became L.A.'s first known COVID-19 patient
item.dc:creator: Harriet Ryan, Paige St. John, Xinlu Liang
item.description: The first confirmed case of COVID-19 in Los Angeles was a man from Wuhan, China, who was hospitalized in a secret ward in January and remained the sole patient diagnosed with the virus here for five weeks.
item.content:encoded: The first confirmed case of COVID-19 in Los Angeles was a man from Wuhan, China, who was hospitalized in a secret ward in January and remained the sole patient diagnosed with the virus here for five weeks.

item.title: Plan to strengthen California's police use of force rules blocked in Sacramento
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: A bill to add tough penalties for police officers who do not intervene when witnessing a fellow officer use excessive force was sidelined in the California Legislature on Thursday. Assembly Bill 1022 by Assemblyman Chris Holden (D-Pasadena) would have made an officer an accessory to a crime if they were capable of stopping an incident of excessive force by another officer and failed to do so.
item.content:encoded: A bill to add tough penalties for police officers who do not intervene when witnessing a fellow officer use excessive force was sidelined in the California Legislature on Thursday. Assembly Bill 1022 by Assemblyman Chris Holden (D-Pasadena) would have made an officer an accessory to a crime if they were capable of stopping an incident of excessive force by another officer and failed to do so.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 30: Protestors are arrested by Los Angeles police in front of City Hall as they demonstrate in downtown on Saturday, May 30, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The protestors demonstrated in response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota. More than 500 arrests were made after looting and vandalism sweep downtown L.A. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Compton Executioners deputy gang lied about guns and hosted inking parties, deputy says
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: 'Ghost guns,' inking parties and a decades-long struggle to crack down on cliques within the Sheriff's Department
item.content:encoded: 'Ghost guns,' inking parties and a decades-long struggle to crack down on cliques within the Sheriff's Department

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Samuel Aldama admitted as part of a lawsuit this year that he has a skull tattoo on his calf associated with the Compton Station, where he worked. The photo of his tattoo emerged in the lawsuit. The department has a long history with deputy tattoos that officials say represent cliques that promote overly aggressive policing. NOTE: The photo is an exhibit to a motion filed in court by plaintiff Andrew Taylor.

item.title: Wildfire damages much of Big Basin Redwoods State Park. Fate of big trees unknown
item.dc:creator: Stuart Leavenworth
item.description: California's oldest state park has suffered extensive damage from the C.Z.U. August Lightning Complex fires.
item.content:encoded: California's oldest state park has suffered extensive damage from the C.Z.U. August Lightning Complex fires.

media:content.media:description: Brian van der Brug Los Angeles Times Andrew Walsh of Ben Lomond explores a hollow tree with son Philip, 2, in Big Basin Redwoods State Park.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Police shooting death of Black man prompts protests in Pasadena
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Authorities on Thursday released body-camera video, which police say shows Anthony McClain was armed with a gun while running away from officers.
item.content:encoded: Authorities on Thursday released body-camera video, which police say shows Anthony McClain was armed with a gun while running away from officers.

media:content.media:description: The Pasadena Police Station. An attorney claims an officer tried to bribe him two years ago.

item.title: L.A. coronavirus cases dropping so low that officials could soon seek to reopen schools
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan, Howard Blume
item.description: As L.A. County's coronavirus cases decline, a top county medical doctor says waivers for reopening elementary schools may soon be possible.
item.content:encoded: As L.A. County's coronavirus cases decline, a top county medical doctor says waivers for reopening elementary schools may soon be possible.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST 19, 2020: Gladys Alvarez, a 5th grade teacher at Manchester Ave. Elementary School in South Los Angeles, talks to her students during a meet and greet on Wednesday afternoon. Alvarez was sitting inside her empty classroom while conducting the virtual zoom class. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Kamala Harris' husband, Doug Emhoff, could also make history
item.dc:creator: Meg James
item.description: Friends say the 55-year-old entertainment lawyer, who attended college and law school in Southern California and lives in L.A.'s Brentwood, would "make an impact" should Biden and Harris win in November.
item.content:encoded: Friends say the 55-year-old entertainment lawyer, who attended college and law school in Southern California and lives in L.A.'s Brentwood, would "make an impact" should Biden and Harris win in November.

media:content.media:description: Kamala Harris with husband Douglas Emhoff on the red carpet at the Broad Museum's gala in September.

item.title: No deal yet in Sacramento to help struggling California renters
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Facing extraordinary circumstances because of the COVID-19 pandemic and a looming deadline for legislative action, California lawmakers on Thursday reduced the number of bills moving forward that deal with the state's affordable housing crisis.
item.content:encoded: Facing extraordinary circumstances because of the COVID-19 pandemic and a looming deadline for legislative action, California lawmakers on Thursday reduced the number of bills moving forward that deal with the state's affordable housing crisis.

media:content.media:description: EL MONTE, CA - MARCH 29: Ian Jameson (left) of El Monte organized hold a sign along with other tenant rights activists assembled at the El Monte City Hall to demand that the El Monte City Council pass an eviction moratorium barring all evictions during the coronavirus pandemic on Sunday, March 29, 2020 in El Monte, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Two L.A. County sheriff's captains are on leave after allegations of sexual misconduct
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Two Los Angeles County sheriff's captains are on administrative leave following allegations of sexual misconduct, according to officials and public safety sources.
item.content:encoded: Two Los Angeles County sheriff's captains are on administrative leave following allegations of sexual misconduct, according to officials and public safety sources.

media:content.media:description: Reserve Deputy Billy Lulo has been fired over alleged diamond theft.

item.title: As excessive heat tapers off, threat of rolling blackouts wanes
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: The California Independent System Operator, which runs the electric grid for most of the state, said further power outages aren't anticipated.
item.content:encoded: The California Independent System Operator, which runs the electric grid for most of the state, said further power outages aren't anticipated.

media:content.media:description: The thermometer at Calvary Church in Woodland Hills registers 116 degree's Fahrenheit.

item.title: Two arrested in hate crime, robbery of transgender women in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Two people have been arrested in connection with the robbery and beating of three transgender women in Hollywood, the LAPD announced.
item.content:encoded: Two people have been arrested in connection with the robbery and beating of three transgender women in Hollywood, the LAPD announced.

media:content.media:description: Place: Hollywood Boulevard Last visited: Fall 2008 My perspective: Most tourists are expecting to see all of the glitz of Hollywood and the sidewalks lined with movie stars. They don't realize that what has been sold to them in the movies and on television is an illusion until they actually get there. All they get to see is a sidewalk, a few interesting old movie theaters and a bunch of shops. Suggested alternative: Getty Museum, Walt Disney Concert Hall --Chris Nunez, Los Angeles
